description: From Middle English seisin, seysen, from Old French seisin, from the verb seisir, from early Medieval Latin sacÄ«re, from the same Proto-Indo-European root as Gothic ğƒğŒ°ğ„ğŒ¾ğŒ°ğŒ½ (satjan) and Old English settan. More at seize, seise.

entries.meaning: (law, historical) An entitlement to a freehold estate with a right to immediate possession; dates from feudal times but is still used in technical discussions of real property law today.
